hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: Let’s check in on your home activity!
hp_check_in.activity_title::eng: Let’s check in on your home activity!
hp_check_in.question_done::eng: Did you have a chance to try this?
hp_check_in.reply_no::eng: That is okay, do not be too hard on yourself. We encourage you to try and do it when you can.
hp_check_in.outro_text::eng: Well done for exploring solutions to your challenges. Go try these solutions out. Your relationship with your child will get stronger and stronger!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did one-on-one time go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your home activity was to spend 5 minutes of one-on-one time with your child.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: That’s wonderful! Well done for spending time together. It lays the foundation for a great relationship with your child!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Sometimes it will be easy and fun to spend time with your child and sometimes it will be difficult. Spending time together will definitely improve your relationship!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry to hear that it was difficult for you to spend time with your child. We all have challenges sometimes. Just be patient with yourself and your child – things will get better. Well done for trying!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did one-on-one time go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your goal was to spend one-on-one time with your teen.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: That’s wonderful! Well done for spending time together. It lays the foundation for a great relationship with your teen!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Sometimes it will be easy and fun to spend time with your teens and sometimes it will be more challenging. Spending time together will definitely improve your relationship!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry to hear that it was difficult for you to spend time with your teen. We all have challenges sometimes. Just be patient with yourself and your teen – things will get better. Well done for trying!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did talking about feelings go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your home activity was to take a moment each day to talk with your child about feelings.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: That’s wonderful! Well done for talking with your child about their feelings. It lays the foundation for a great relationship with your child!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Talking about feelings can be both easy and tough at times. The effort you put in to discuss them will surely help strengthen your bond!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry to hear it was challenging to talk about feelings. It’s normal to face difficulties sometimes. Keep being patient with yourself and your child – it will get easier. Good job for making the effort!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did praising your child go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your home activity was to praise your child for 2 things every day.
hp_check_in.reply_no::eng:
It can sometimes be hard to remember to praise our children. 

Next time you spend one-on-one time with your child, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. You can even say, “Thank you for spending time with me!”
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well! Keep up the praise – you will see your child do more and more of the behaviour you like to see!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: It sometimes takes a bit of time to adjust to praising, but it makes a big difference – you will see.
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry that you struggled with this. Starting with praise can take some practice, but you will see the positive results soon!
hp_check_in.outro_text::eng: You deserve some praise, too. Thank you again for using @global.app_name. It shows you really care!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did praising your teen go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your goal was to praise your teen once a day.
hp_check_in.reply_no::eng: It can sometimes be hard to remember to praise our teens. Next time you spend one-on-one time with your teen, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. You can even say, “Thank you for spending time with me!”
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well! Keep up the praise – you will see your teen do more and more of the behaviour you like to see!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: It sometimes takes a bit of time to adjust to praising, but it makes a big difference – you will see.
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry that you struggled with this. Starting with praise can take some practice, but you will see the positive results soon!
hp_check_in.outro_text::eng: You deserve some praise, too. Thank you again for using @global.app_name. It shows you really care!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did giving clear instructions go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your home activity was to give your child specific, realistic, and positive instructions.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well. You are a star!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Sorry to hear it was difficult for you. Well done for trying!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Giving instructions in a new way takes some practice. Keep trying, you will soon see the difference it makes!
hp_check_in.outro_text::eng:
Thank you for sharing! Well done for trying to give your child positive instructions and for building a positive relationship with your child. 

Your child deserves praise and YOU do as well!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did making a rule and routine go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your goal was to make ONE rule and ONE routine with your child.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well! Consistent rules help make our child feel secure and keep them safe!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: It can be hard to create your first rule together, but you will see the benefits of involving your family. Keep trying!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry that this has been difficult. Creating rules together requires some practice but it is worth it!
hp_check_in.outro_text::eng: Well done for this! It is not easy, and children will not keep to the rules all the time, but making a few key rules together is a great start. Praise yourself for trying this – we are proud of you!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did talking about consequences go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your home activity was to discuss one household rule that your child finds hard to follow and agree on a fair consequence together.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well! Getting consequences right helps children behave better and makes family life calmer.
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Staying calm and consistent can be hard, but you are doing so well. You can do this!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry to hear that this was difficult for you. Setting consequences together will make your child want to follow the rules more often!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did solving a problem together go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng:
Your goal was to to identify a problem your child may have and practise the four steps of problem-solving together: 
Know It, Solve It, Try It, Reflect.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well! When your child learns how to solve problems, they can use that skill their whole life. What a gift to give them!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Solving problems together takes some practice. The more often you involve your child when you are both calm, the better it will go. Well done for trying!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry to hear that this was hard. Sometimes we just have to keep trying. Find a time when you and your child are calm and try again to talk through a problem using the four steps of problem-solving. Together, you can do so much!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did solving a problem together go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your goal was to try and resolve a problem together with your teen using the four steps of problem-solving: Know It, Solve It, Try It, Test It.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well! When your teen learns how to solve problems, they can use that skill their whole life. What a gift!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Solving problems together takes some practice. The more often you involve your teen when you are both calm, the better it will go. Well done for trying!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry that this was hard. Sometimes we just have to keep trying. Find a time when you and your teen are calm and try again to talk through a problem using the four steps of problem-solving. Together, you can do so much!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did taking care of yourself go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your home activity was to pause, praise your efforts and reward yourself.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear you took time for yourself! Taking care of yourself helps you be the best parent you can be.
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Taking time for yourself can be challenging, but you’re doing great. Keep it up — you deserve it!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry to hear that it was difficult to prioritise yourself. Remember, taking care of yourself is essential and will help you take care of others even better!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did taking care of yourself go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your home activity was to relax, recognise your efforts, and reward yourself.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear you took time for yourself! Taking care of yourself helps you be the best parent you can be.
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Taking time for yourself can be challenging, but you’re doing great. Keep it up — you deserve it!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry to hear that it was difficult to prioritise yourself. Remember, taking care of yourself is essential and will help you take care of others even better!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did playing with your child go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your home activity was to play with your child.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: That is great to hear! Spending time with your child is a great way to build a good relationship with them!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Every time you play with your child, you’re building something special, even if it doesn’t always go perfectly. Well done for staying committed!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry to hear that it was hard. Sometimes it takes a few tries to find the right way. Keep trying, and remember that playtime is a valuable way to connect with your child. You’re doing your best, and that’s what matters!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did giving clear instructions go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your home practice was to give your teen positive instructions.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well. You are a star!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Sorry to hear it was difficult for you. Well done for trying!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Giving instructions in a new way takes some practice. Keep trying, you will soon see the difference it makes!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did keeping calm under stress go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng:
This week, your goal was to respond calmly and talk to your teen about how you both felt in a stressful situation.

Your other goal was to pick a Safety Word together.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Wonderful! You deserve all the happy times!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Sorry that this was difficult for you. You are a star for trying!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Life can be so stressful. Every small step counts. Keep up the good work!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did setting a rule go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your goal was to set one rule together with your teen.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well! Consistent rules help make our teens feel secure and keep them safe!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: It can be hard to create your first rule together, but you will see the benefits of involving your family. Keep trying!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry that this has been difficult. Creating rules together requires some practice but it is worth it!
hp_check_in.outro_text::eng: Well done for this! It is not easy, and teenagers will not keep to the rules all the time, but making a few key rules together is a great start. Praise yourself for trying this – we are proud of you!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did introducing a positive consequence go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your goal was to introduce one POSITIVE consequence (for your teen taking good actions) and one NEGATIVE consequence (for your teen breaking a household rule).
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well! Getting consequences right helps teens behave better and makes family life calmer.
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Staying calm and consistent can be hard, but you are doing so well. You can do this!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry that this was difficult for you. Setting consequences together will make your teen want to follow the rules more often!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did making safety maps go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your goal was to make two maps with your teen of safe and unsafe places – both in your community and online.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well! Talking about risks and support options prevents problems and really helps to keep your teen safe.
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Even if it did not go so well yet, you will get there! Mapping risks and support systems together will help your family. Well done for trying.
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry that this was hard. Mapping risks and places to get support can be challenging and emotional. It really does help to keep your teen safe!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did talking about a crisis plan go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your goal was to discuss a possible crisis situation with your teen and make a plan for how you could respond together.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: It can be hard to think and talk about a crisis happening in your family. By trying you are already on the right path. Keep up the good work!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry it didn’t go so well. This can be tough. Try sitting down with your teen again — and think about whether someone they trust could join the conversation to help.

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did making a family budget go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your goal was to make a family budget.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well. Talking about your finances together really makes your family stronger!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: It is never easy to talk about money. Well done on starting the conversation and teaching your teen about this.
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry to hear it was difficult for you. Well done for trying. Helping your teen understand money better will benefit them so much in life!
hp_check_in.outro_text::eng:
Thank you for sharing your experiences! Well done for thinking about how you can budget and save with your family. This will really help you to work towards your family goals.

Together you can achieve so many good things!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did reading the stories and talking about body changes go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your goal was to look at the stories in this module together with your teen and use them to start a conversation about body changes and relationships.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Well done for trying it out – you took a very important step to help your teen!
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Talking about these sensitive topics can be uncomfortable for both you and your teen. The more you try, the better it will get. It is worth every bit of your effort!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: It can be hard to talk to your teen about these things. That is okay. Well done for trying, you will get another opportunity again soon!
hp_check_in.outro_text::eng: It can be hard to find resources! Go to your nearest clinic or another support service and ask what resources they may have available.

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did talking about staying safe with your teen go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your goal was to discuss the Staying Safe module with your teen.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Well done for involving your teen! Discussing these difficult topics can help keep your teen safe when it matters most.
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Talking about potentially dangerous situations with your teen can be challenging, but just know that you started an important conversation! Keep up the good work.
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Discussing potential dangers and how to respond can be a trigger for any parent and teen. The fact that you tried already makes a big difference and really shows you care.

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did sharing feelings of grief with your teen go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: This week, your goal was to share with your teen how you feel, and ask them to also name their feelings.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Well done! Sharing feelings will help your family to support each other and get through this difficult time together.
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Talking about feelings can be challenging at first. Try again another time. It will help you and your family.
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Losing someone impacts everyone differently. Be kind to yourself and take some time to notice and share how you feel when you are ready. You will see it will help you and your family.

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did trying a fun activity with your teen go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your goal was to try a fun activity with your teen.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well! Spending fun, relaxed time with your teen helps them learn important life skills  —  and it strengthens your bond.
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: You're doing well! Even small moments of fun and conversation can help your teen feel valued and motivated. Keep it up!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Taking time for yourself can be challenging, but you’re doing great. Keep it up — you deserve it!

hp_check_in.notification_text::eng: How did making an Online Family Agreement with your teen go?
hp_check_in.text_goal::eng: Your goal was to make an Online Family Agreement with your teen.
hp_check_in.reply_happy::eng: Great to hear it went well! Creating an Online Family Agreement together can help your teen feel trusted and supported.
hp_check_in.reply_ok::eng: Talking about these sensitive topics can be uncomfortable for both you and your teen. The more you try, the better it will get. It is worth every bit of your effort!
hp_check_in.reply_sad::eng: Sorry it was difficult this time. Talking about online behaviour can be tricky, especially when teens value their privacy. Try again another day when you’re both calm.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I did not have enough time
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng:
It can be hard to find time with work, chores, and everything else.

Try to find 5 minutes during moments you already share with your child – like school runs, wake-ups, or during bedtime.

Need ideas for activities? Tap the ‘Play’ button at the bottom of the App.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: My child did not want to spend one-on-one time with me
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
It can hurt when your child does not want to spend one-on-one time with you.

Think to yourself: When are they more open to you? In the morning? Right before bedtime?

Try again so that your child can see that you care and want to spend this time with them.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: All my child wanted to do was watch T.V. or play with a gadget
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng:
Children often want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget.

You could watch or play on the gadget with them – showing interest is a great first step!

Once you begin spending time together you can suggest another activity.

Need ideas for activities? Tap the ‘Play’ button at the bottom of the App.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: My child wanted to do activities that I could not physically do
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng:
If your child wants to do things that are too difficult for you to do, you could watch them.

You could describe what they are doing like a sports announcer.

You can also show enthusiasm by clapping, smiling, or offering a thumbs-up.

Praise them while they do it!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_5::eng: My child chose a competitive activity. I won and then they got angry
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_5::eng:
Competitive games can be tough if your child doesn’t like losing.

Once they’ve calmed down, talk about what it means to win or lose kindly.

Try suggesting activities where you work together instead of compete.

Need ideas for activities? Tap the ‘Play’ button at the bottom of the App.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_6::eng: All my children wanted one-on-one time at the same time
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_6::eng:
It can be hard to find time with work, chores, and everything else.

Try to find 5 minutes during moments you already share with your child — like school runs, wake-ups, or during bedtime.

Need ideas for activities? Tap the ‘Play’ button at the bottom of the App.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I did not have enough time
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng:
Yes, it can be really hard to find time during the day, with work, chores, and everything else.

You’re doing great by making the effort to connect!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: My teen does not want to spend time with me
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
Sorry that you struggled with that. It can make us feel bad if our children do not want to spend one-on-one time with us.

You’re doing great by making the effort to connect!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: My teen only wants to watch TV or play on his/her phone
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng:
Sorry that you had that challenge. Teens often want to spend time watching TV or playing with a gadget. 

You could watch or play on the gadget with them – showing interest is a great first step!

Once you begin spending time together you can suggest another activity.

Need ideas for activities? Tap the ‘Play’ button at the bottom of the App.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: My teen wants to do things that are not safe or that cost money
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: You are not alone here. Many parents have this challenge, too. One-on-one time should always be safe and it does not have to cost a thing!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_5::eng: My teen wants to do things that I cannot physically do
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_5::eng:
Sorry to hear that. Teens can feel sad if we can’t do what they want, like playing sports or other active things.

But the most important thing is spending time together – and that can look different for every family.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_6::eng: All my children want one-on-one time with me at the same time
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_6::eng:
Many parents face this. It can be difficult to spend one-on-one time with our teens when we have more than one child.

You can also spend time with all your children together — just make sure everyone can join in.

Need ideas for activities? Tap the ‘Play’ button at the bottom of the App.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I did not have enough time
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng:
It’s okay! Life gets busy. Try setting aside just 5 minutes at the same time every day. 

You’re doing great by making the effort to connect!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: My child did not want to share their feelings
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
It’s normal for children to feel shy about sharing feelings, especially at first.

Keep being patient and give them chances to talk. You’re doing well by showing them how – like saying, “I feel happy!”
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: I felt uncomfortable talking about my feelings
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng:
It’s okay to feel that way! Start small and use ‘I feel…’ to ease into it.

You’re taking a brave step in being open, and that’s something to be proud of!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: Others in the household don’t think it’s a good idea to talk about emotions
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng:
It’s okay if not everyone agrees at first.

Try talking with them about why it might help, and gently encourage them to give it a try.

You’re doing something important by supporting open communication!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_5::eng: Others in the household don’t think it’s a good idea to talk about negative emotions
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_5::eng:
It’s okay to feel unsure about this.

You can explain that talking about sad or angry feelings helps us feel better and brings us closer to others. Encourage them to give it a try.

You’re showing care by helping your child understand their feelings.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_6::eng: I don’t know how to name some of the feelings I am experiencing
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_6::eng:
That’s okay! It can be hard to find the right words.

Try combining the names of emotions you do know. 

You’re doing a great job by simply acknowledging your feelings!

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I forgot to do the activity
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng:
Many parents face this. It can be difficult to spend one-on-one time with our teens when we have more than one child.

You can also spend time with all your children together — just make sure everyone can join in.

Need ideas for activities? Tap the ‘Play’ button at the bottom of the App.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: My child was surprised or suspicious
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng: Remember, it takes some time for your child to get used to seeing you praise them. The more time you spend with them, the better it will go!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: My child did not like it
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: It happens – just be patient. Try to remember to ask your child to decide what activity they would like to do with you. This will make it more likely that they enjoy the activity too.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: It felt unnatural
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng:
That’s completely normal. If you’re not used to giving praise, it can feel strange at first. Start with something simple, like “Thanks for helping with that.” 

The more you praise, the easier it becomes — and it really helps build your child's confidence.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I forgot to do the activity
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: It can sometimes be hard to remember to praise our teens. Next time you spend one-on-one time with your teen, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. You can even say, “Thank you for spending time with me!”
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: My teen was surprised or suspicious
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng: Remember, it takes some time for your teen to get used to seeing you praise them. The more time you spend with them, the better it will go!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: My teen did not like it
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: It happens – just be patient. Make sure to keep spending time with your teen, so they will value your opinion more and more. When your praise is genuine, you will see the benefits soon!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: It felt unnatural
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng:
That’s completely normal. If you’re not used to giving praise, it can feel strange at first. Start with something simple, like “Thanks for helping with that.” 

The more you give praise, the easier it becomes — and it really helps build your teen’s confidence.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I forgot to do the activity
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: It can be really hard to find time during the day, with work, chores, and everything else. You're doing great, try to do it when you can!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: My child did not follow my instructions even when I used the tips
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng: Children need time to learn to follow instructions. Be patient. Try again. Remember to praise them every time they follow an instruction.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: It is hard to remember to use positive words when giving instructions
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: This is difficult to remember for everyone at first! Try to take a breath before giving an instruction. Also, remember to be gentle with yourself when you forget. It happens to everyone!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: I shouted at my child when they behaved negatively instead of giving them a positive instruction for what they should do
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: It’s difficult to give instructions in a calm way when we are still angry. Try to find a time when you are calm or to use a calming strategy like Take a Pause before you introduce a positive instruction.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I forgot to do the activity
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: That is okay. Some days are full and we forget things. When you have a bit of time, you can try it then. Every time you practise, it helps.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: My child could not agree on one specific rule or routine
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
When creating rules, it is important to think about the age of each child so you can come up with routines that are fair for their age.

This is most important for bedtime, the time to come home, and household chores.

Try to agree on a small and meaningful incentive that can motivate your child to follow the rule. Consider options like playing a 15-minute board game with the family, choosing the food for the day, or enjoying a 30-minute trip to the park.

What other ideas come to mind?
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: My child felt it was unfair that they had to follow the rule while I didn’t have to follow it
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng:
Our children learn best from us.

The more we follow the rules, the more they will follow the rules too.

You can adapt the rule to make sure that it is something everyone can follow.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: I felt uncomfortable because I think an adult should create the rule, not my child
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng:
When we create rules together with our children, we build trust and an open relationship with them.

The rules we set will be more realistic and your child will be more willing and able to follow the rules.

Think about the valuable lessons you’ll be teaching Your Child, such as working together and taking initiative.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_5::eng: We were not able to stick to the rule
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_5::eng: The rule needs to be specific and realistic. Make sure to have a rule that can be kept easily, like having one meal together every Sunday instead of every night. Do you need to be more flexible about the rules?

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I got very angry when my child broke the rule
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng:
When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better. 

Next time your child makes you angry, try to take a pause first. Even a few deep breaths can make a big difference!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: My child got very angry with me after I gave the consequence
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng: Try talking to them about why the rule is important to follow. You can also discuss the consequence with them, so that they feel it is fair and realistic.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: I introduced the consequence without first discussing it with my child
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: Can you create a consequence if this happens again? When we establish a consequence together with our child, the consequence will be more realistic, and our child will be more willing and able to follow the rule.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: I forgot to follow through with the consequence
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: We all make mistakes! The more consistent we are with our consequences, the more likely our children will choose to behave positively in the future.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_5::eng: Even with the consequence, my child still does not follow the rule
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_5::eng:
If your child keeps breaking rules, you might need to spend more positive time with them. 

Try to keep going with your other goals — like self-care, one-on-one time, and praise. All these skills will help your child feel more loved and secure… and you, less stressed!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_6::eng: My child suggested being hit as a negative consequence
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_6::eng:
Children can be used to seeing hitting as the only possible consequence for breaking rules. 

Brainstorm some calm consequences with them that could help them understand that they have done something wrong. These will be more effective and will set positive examples!

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I got very angry when my teen broke the rules
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng:
When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better.

Next time your teen makes you angry, try to take a pause first. Even a few deep breaths can make a big difference!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: My teen got very angry with me after I gave the consequences
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
When your teen gets angry, you might need to walk away until you are both calm.

Check to make sure your consequence is fair and reasonable. Listen to your teen’s explanation and react calmly as you agreed if they used the “Safety Word” or broke a rule in order to stay safe.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: I introduced the consequence without first discussing it with my teen
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: Can you make a consequence if this happens again? When we establish a consequence together with our teens, the consequence will be more realistic and our teens will be more willing and able to follow the rule.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: Even with the consequence, my teen still does not follow the rule
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng:
If your child keeps breaking rules, you might need to spend more positive time with them. 

Try to keep going with your other goals — like self-care, one-on-one time, and praise. All these skills will help your child feel more loved and secure… and you, less stressed!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_5::eng: We only created a negative consequence, not a positive consequence
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_5::eng: It can be difficult to think of positive consequences sometimes. Positive consequences will encourage your teen to take more responsibility and you will see the difference!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_6::eng: My teen suggested being hit as a negative consequence
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_6::eng:
Teens can be used to seeing hitting as the only possible consequence for breaking rules.

Think together of some calm consequences that could help them understand that they have done something wrong. These will be more effective and will set positive examples!

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I forgot the steps of problem-solving
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: It takes some practice to use all four steps of problem-solving. Next time a problem comes up, look at the four steps together with your child — it will make a big difference!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: I started with the solutions right away
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
When we have a problem, we often want to get to the quickest end result and can forget about the steps. 

To come up with the best solution together, it is helpful to first have a full understanding of the problem and the different solutions.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: We could not agree on a solution to try out and we got into an argument
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng:
Sometimes it can be difficult to agree with everyone in the family, especially if everyone is not calm. 

You can try one solution first, then try another if needed. If things get stuck, take a break and come back later to decide together.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: It takes some practice to use all four steps of problem-solving. Next time a problem comes up, look at the four steps together with your child — it will make a big difference!
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: When a problem comes up, we all get angry or stressed sometimes. Remember, when you feel angry or stressed, you can take a pause to help you stay calm and then solve the problem you are facing.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_5::eng: My child got angry and did not want to talk about the problem
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_5::eng: Your child might be too overwhelmed to deal with the problem right away. Recognise and name their emotions. Create a time later in the day or week to discuss and solve the problem together. By giving your child time, the problem can be solved well.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I forgot the steps of problem-solving
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: It takes some practice to use all four steps of problem solving. Next time a problem comes up, look at the four steps together with your teen – it will make a big difference!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: I started with the solutions right away
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
When we have a problem, we often want to get to the quickest end result and can forget about the steps. 

To come up with the best solution together, it is helpful to first have a full understanding of the problem and the different solutions.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: We could not agree on a solution to try out and we got into an argument
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng:
Sometimes it can be difficult to agree with everyone in the family, especially if everyone is not calm. 

You can try one solution first, then try another if needed. If things get stuck, take a break and come back later to decide together.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: I got angry when the problem came up and I forgot to use the problem-solving steps
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: When a problem comes up, we all get angry or stressed sometimes. Remember, when you feel angry or stressed, you can take a pause to help you stay calm and then solve the problem you are facing.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_5::eng: My teen got angry and did not want to talk about the problem
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_5::eng: Your teen might be too overwhelmed to deal with the problem right away. Recognise and name their emotions. Create a time later in the day or week to discuss and solve the problem together. By giving your teen time, the problem can be solved well.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I forgot to do the activity
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: It happens! Life gets busy. You could try setting a reminder or choosing a regular time each week to make it easier to remember.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: I didn’t understand the activity
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng: That’s okay. Self-care can mean different things to different people. It could be anything that helps you feel calmer or more rested — like taking a short walk, listening to music, or having a quiet moment to yourself. Try starting small.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: It didn't feel right to take time for myself
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: That’s okay. Self-care can mean different things to different people. It could be anything that helps you feel calmer or more rested — like taking a short walk, listening to music, or having a quiet moment to yourself. Try starting small.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: I was too tired to do anything for myself
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: That’s completely understandable. When you’re exhausted, self-care can feel like one more task. Start with something very small — even resting is a form of self-care.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I forgot to do the activity
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: It happens! Life gets busy. You could try setting a reminder or choosing a regular time each week to make it easier to remember.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: I didn’t understand the activity
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng: That’s okay. Self-care can mean different things to different people. It could be anything that helps you feel calmer or more rested — like taking a short walk, listening to music, or having a quiet moment to yourself. Try starting small.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: It didn't feel right to take time for myself
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: That’s okay. Self-care can mean different things to different people. It could be anything that helps you feel calmer or more rested — like taking a short walk, listening to music, or having a quiet moment to yourself. Try starting small.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: I was too tired to do anything for myself
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: That’s completely understandable. When you’re exhausted, self-care can feel like one more task. Start with something very small — even resting is a form of self-care.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I don’t have time to play with my child
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng:
It’s okay to feel that way. There are many small ways to spend time with your children!

You can talk with your child while doing other things. For example, ask them to name colours or things they see while you walk or ride the bus.

Even short moments like these show your child you care.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: My child is not interested in playing with me
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
You may feel hurt because Your Child doesn't want to spend time with you. It is important to give them their space, be patient and listen to what is happening to her or him. Open yourself to opportunities to play with them another time.

Sometimes, Your Child just needs time to engage with you. It helps to remain calm, patient, and kind while you try to connect with Your Child.

As girls and boys grow, they may want independence from you. That’s normal! You can support them to find friends based on their interests.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: My child keeps getting hurt from exploring or making new friends
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng:
It can be hard to see your child get hurt or feel sad.

But making mistakes is how children learn and grow. As long as you’re aware of what they’re doing and keep them safe from danger, they’ll be okay.

Encourage them to try fun, safe activities with others – and praise them when they do well.

Let your child know you trust them to be safe and follow your rules.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: My child likes competitive activities but gets angry when they lose or need to share the win
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng:
Competitive games can be tough if your child doesn’t like losing.

Once they’ve calmed down, talk about what it means to win or lose kindly.

Try suggesting activities where you work together instead of compete.

Need ideas for activities? Tap the ‘Play’ button at the bottom of the App.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: My teenager did not want to follow the instruction
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: Our teens need time to learn to follow instructions. Be patient, try again, and remember to praise them every time they follow an instruction!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: I did not find time to spend one-on-one time with my teen
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
Getting used to giving positive instructions can take time. Try finding a few minutes each day to practise. 

You can try asking your teen or someone else to help out with a chore at home, so you have more time to practice this new skill.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: I gave a negative instead of a positive instruction
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: Yes, it takes some time to get used to giving positive instructions – it is really worth trying again! Think about the behaviour you would love to see your teen do more and think of positive ways to give that instruction!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: I shouted at my teen instead of giving them a positive instruction for what they should do
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: It is difficult to come up with instructions while we are still angry. Try and find a time when you are calm to introduce a positive instruction to your teen.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I was afraid my teen would think I was weak
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: Sharing feelings, especially the difficult ones, sets an important example for your teen! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: I felt uncomfortable about naming specific difficult feelings
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
Being specific is not rude or insensitive – it really helps others to understand you clearly and this prevents confusion in the family. 

Feelings, like anger and stress, are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is handle our emotions well by taking a few deep breaths before responding.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: My teen felt uncomfortable when I shared my feelings
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it and keep showing a good example by observing and sharing your feelings. Over time, your teen will learn to do the same, and they will feel even more loved and cared for!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: When I shared my feelings, my teen asked many questions, which made me uncomfortable
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: Sharing feelings helps your teen to be aware and learn to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It is up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later by saying, *“I am feeling angry/stressed now. Could you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight.”

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: My teen and I could not agree on a rule
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: Think about whether the rule is reasonable. Can your teen follow it? When making rules as a family, it helps to think about your teen, how old they are and what is important to them.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: My teen felt it was unfair that they have to follow the rule while I dont have to follow it
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
We should always remember that our teens learn best from us. The more we follow the rules, the more they will follow the rules, too.

You can adjust the rule to make sure that it is realistic for everyone to follow.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: I felt uncomfortable because I feel that I should be the one making the rule, not my teen
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: When we make rules together with our teens, that helps the family to understand each other better. The rules will be more realistic, and our teens will be more willing and able to follow the rules.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: My partner felt uncomfortable, because they feel that they should be the one making the rule, not the teen
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: When we establish rules together with our teens, that helps the family to understand each other better. The rules will be more realistic, and our teens will be more willing and able to follow the rules.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_5::eng: When we tried to set a rule, we got into an argument
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_5::eng: Was your teen in a good mood when you tried to set the rule? It is best to set rules when the situation is calm. If you or your teen are tired or hungry, it is better to talk about rules at a later time.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_6::eng: We were not able to stick to the rule
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_6::eng: The rule needs to be specific and realistic. Make sure to have a rule that can be kept easily, like having one meal together every Sunday instead of every night.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: My teen and I disagree on which areas and online activities were unsafe
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: Well done for trying the activity! When we listen to our teenagers, even if we disagree, we learn to understand their thinking. Try and find time to do the activity again – try to really listen and show you understand them before sharing your thoughts.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: My teen identified the house of someone I trust as unsafe. I was shocked and did not know what to do
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng: It is shocking to learn that people who are close to us and who we trust may be a danger to our teens. Remember to take a pause when you are upset and try to listen calmly to your teen. Find someone you can talk to about this, perhaps a friend or support service, so you can get the support you need.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: My teen thinks a place is safe, but I don’t agree. I’m not sure how to talk to them about it
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: This can be very frustrating. To find a solution, your teen needs to feel heard – so listen calmly to your teen's reasons and only then share your own thoughts. Then, think together about a rule that allows them to have fun but stay safe.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: As an adult, I feel responsible to protect — but when I told my teen what is safe and what is not, my teen got angry
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: Our teenagers may know things about our communities and technology that we are not aware of. When we actively involve our teens in the mapping activity and really listen to them, they feel heard and valued, and it can be easier to come up with a plan that everyone agrees on.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_5::eng: It was hard to identify support resources available in my community
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_5::eng: It is difficult to know every detail about our communities. Involve another family member or friend in your mapping activity. You can even visit some of the services available and ask what they do. The more we know, the better we can keep our families safe!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_6::eng: I do not know much about technology, so I do not know how to talk about it with my teen
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_6::eng:
That is totally fine! You can still support your teen. Ask your teen to explain the gadgets they use — you could do this during one-on-one time. 

This is a great opportunity to show interest in your teen’s life and to discuss potential risks together. If you are not sure which rules to set, you can always agree, with your teen, to try a new rule for two weeks and then discuss how things are going and change the rule if needed!

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: My teen told me that something serious happened to them and I did not know how to handle it
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: Praise your teen for telling you, that is not easy to do! Remember, you can use all the skills you picked from your toolbox: Take a pause, use the four steps of problem solving and reach out to get the support you and your teen need!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: The conversation made me very uncomfortable because I was reminded of a negative experience I had
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng: When we are reminded of such experiences, it is normal to feel upset or angry. It is important to find a time when you are calm, so that you can think of what support you need. You may need to talk to someone.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: One of us did not feel comfortable
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: This is difficult stuff to talk about. Find a relaxing time for it. We know it is much easier to not talk about these things and to hope they will never happen to us. However, learning to deal with crises is like getting insurance — it is ALWAYS best to be prepared.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I did not want to tell my family how much I earn
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: You do not have to reveal the exact amount you earn; you could give an estimate. You could say, “In this household, we have R2000 every month” rather than, “I make R2000.”
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: When budgeting, we could not agree on what should fall under needs and what should fall under wants
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng: People’s wants and needs are different sometimes. Talking about them together can help you and your teen to understand each other, respect your differences and see where you can compromise.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: I did not understand what to do
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: I am sorry to hear this. I know it can be difficult! Why don’t you try to go through the module again? Your teen or other family members can join and help you!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: My teen did not want to do the budgeting with me
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng:
Try making the budget with other adults in your home first. Your teen may get interested in what you are doing.

Making a budget may sound serious but try to make it fun — make it a game during one-on-one time!

Remember to praise them when you are done!

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: It made me uncomfortable
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng:
Talking about body changes, intimate relationships, and sex can be uncomfortable – many parents feel this way!

Remember, these are all normal parts of life. The more you talk about them and educate your teen, the more prepared they are for keeping themselves healthy and safe.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: It made my teen uncomfortable
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
Teens often do not want to speak to their parents about body changes, intimate relationships, and sex. Tell your teen that that is normal and you also went through this.

If they do not want to talk to you, give them resources so they can learn about the topic. Tell your teen that you are happy to speak with them any time!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: I do not know where to find resources to support my teen's development
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: It can be hard to find resources! Go to your nearest clinic or another support service and ask what resources they may have available.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: My teen and/or I felt uncomfortable
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng:
Talking about potential dangers in our direct environment is never easy. However, dangerous situations can happen to anyone and helping your teen be prepared can make the biggest difference to keep them safe.

Try to have another conversation or practise with your teen so you can both get more confident with your new skills to stay safe.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: I discovered my teen experienced a dangerous situation or trauma
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
It can be hard for teens to open up about a difficult situation or trauma they experienced, especially if it happened while they were in a place or with people that you may not approve of as a parent. 

Remember to breathe and listen to what your teen needs. You can find support together if needed.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: The conversation reminded me of a difficult experience I had
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng:
It is normal to feel upset or angry when we are reminded of such experiences. Think about what support you may need. Taking good care of yourself is essential for taking good care of your family.

Once you are in a calmer space, you can try again to talk to your teen about how they can stay safe.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I was afraid my teen would think I was weak.
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: Sharing feelings, especially the difficult ones, sets an important example for your teen! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: I felt uncomfortable about naming specific difficult feelings
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng:
Being specific is not rude or insensitive – it really helps others to understand you clearly and this prevents confusion in the family. 

Feelings, like anger and stress, are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is handle our emotions well by taking a few deep breaths before responding.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: My teen felt uncomfortable when I shared my feelings
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it and keep showing a good example by observing and sharing your feelings. Over time, your teen will learn to do the same, and they will feel even more loved and cared for!
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: When I shared my feelings, my teen asked many questions, which made me uncomfortable
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: Sharing feelings helps your teen to be aware and learn to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It is up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later by saying, *“I am feeling angry/stressed now. Could you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight.”*
hp_challenges.text_challenge_5::eng: I was too sad or overwhelmed to try sharing my feelings — I prefer to be alone when I feel like that
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_5::eng: It is okay to not want to share at that time. Find some time to explain later, when you feel calmer, so that everyone can understand.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: I did not have enough time
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: That’s okay — it can be hard to find time. Try starting with something small, like helping them with one task or asking about their day. Every bit helps.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: My teen wasn't interested in the activity
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng: It can be tough when teens seem not interested. Try letting them choose the activity next time — it might help them feel more involved.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: I felt unsure what kind of activity would help with learning
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: That’s okay. It doesn’t have to be school-related — even cooking or watching a video together can be a chance to learn and connect.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: We did something together, but I don’t think it helped
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: It’s normal to wonder if it’s working. Just spending time together builds connection and supports learning — even if it doesn’t seem obvious right away.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_5::eng: I tried, but my teen was too busy
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_5::eng: Teens often have full schedules. Try asking when they’re free, or offer to join something they’re already doing — even briefly.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_6::eng: My teen chose a competitive activity. I won and s/he got angry
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_6::eng:
Competitive activities can be tough if your teen doesn’t like losing.

Once they’ve calmed down, talk about what it means to win or lose kindly.

Try suggesting activities where you work together instead of compete.

Need ideas for activities? Tap the ‘Play’ button at the bottom of the App.

hp_challenges.text_challenge_1::eng: My teen refused to make or sign the agreement
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_1::eng: That’s okay. Start by listening to what bothers them. Suggest a short trial: they choose one rule and you choose one. Keep it simple, try it for one week, then review together.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_2::eng: We disagreed about screen-time limits
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_2::eng: Pick one small change (e.g., no phones at dinner) and agree on exceptions for homework. Use a timer and review in a week.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_3::eng: We could not agree on social media / app rules
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_3::eng: Check age ratings and privacy settings together. Agree to keep accounts private, approve followers, and “ask before new apps.” Try these for two weeks, then adjust.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_4::eng: I did not have time to make the agreement with my teen
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_4::eng: That’s okay — life gets busy. Try finding a calm moment, like during dinner or before bedtime, to start with just one small rule together. yes My teen refused to make or sign the agreement.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_5::eng: I do not know enough about technology to set fair rules
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_5::eng: Ask your teen to teach you during one-on-one time. Start with three basics: privacy settings, how to block/report, and “tell me if something worries you.” Set one rule per topic and test it.
hp_challenges.text_challenge_6::eng: My partner and I had different ideas about online rules
hp_challenges.reply_challenge_6::eng: Keep it consistent. Talk privately with your partner first and agree on two or three shared rules before discussing them with your teen. This helps everyone stay on the same page.
